statement_html:
Given a differentiable function \(\displaystyle f\), recall that there are two definitions for \(\displaystyle f'(a)\) :

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x - a}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}\end{aligned}\]

Pick one of these definitions and draw a picture to illustrate the fact that the limit on the right-hand side is the limit of slopes of secant lines. Make sure to include the labels \(a\) and \(f(a)\).
statement_raw:
Given a differentiable function <math>\displaystyle f</math>, recall that there are two definitions for <math>\displaystyle f'(a)</math> : 
: <math> \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x - a} </math>

and 

: <math> \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}</math>

Pick one of these definitions and draw a picture to illustrate the fact that the limit on the right-hand side is the limit of slopes of secant lines.  Make sure to include the labels <math>a</math> and <math>f(a)</math>.
